poem:
**Glitz on the High Street**

In East Grinstead, where whispers flit,  
Tom Cruise strides past Iceland's door,  
a fleeting star in mundane streets,  
an unexpected glamour weeps  
into cobblestones, brief yet alive—  
a portrait of dreams  
in a town's everyday pulse.  
Moments flash and fade,  
but the memory stays,  
glossed and grand  
like a cruise through fame.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It seemed like quite a do’: why East Grinstead hosts one of Scientology’s glitziest evenings In the nearly 30 years that Diane Juchau has lived in East Grinstead, not many days live as long in the memory as the day she saw Tom Cruise on the high street. “I saw him a couple of years ago walking past Iceland,” she said. It may seem like a once-in-a-lifetime anecdote but, this week, Cruise was back –". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: ‘It seemed like quite a do’: why East Grinstead hosts one of Scientology’s glitziest evenings In the nearly 30 years that Diane Juchau has lived in East Grinstead, not many days live as long in the memory as the day she saw Tom Cruise on the high street. “I saw him a couple of years ago walking past Iceland,” she said. It may seem like a once-in-a-lifetime anecdote but, this week, Cruise was back –
